utterances: I've had been an Edwards fan for quite awhile, but the more I watched the debates, the more impressed I am with Hillary Clinton.
She always has a good answer, she doesn't fumble, she doesn't stumble.
I do wonder again if she can win a general election, although, I certainly don't see anything on the Republican side that could hold the candle to her.
Competence and experience clearly matter to Susan Dersey(ph).
She hosted this special meeting of the Crones at her house in Frederick.
The YouTube debate on CNN got me thinking about how easy it would be for her to put it together a cabinet.
She knows how the government runs.
She knows a lot of people.
And I think that she could form a new government fairly quickly, get people into cabinet positions and get things going.
What about that idea that Hillary Clinton is polarizing?
Several women raised it, including Myrna Whitworth.
And knowing how she was in the White House with Hillary land and this very secretive group, those coterie of women that she had around her, I think that that's the way she does business.
And I am concerned that the person that needs to be present now is somebody that will reach out and bring this country together.
And what about Bill Clinton?
He caused a great deal of trouble for himself with his behavior in the White House.
Would he be a problem for his wife?
Liz Whitelaw(ph) is a retired health worker.
She sees a soap opera.
Well, we're going to have a continuing soap opera in the White House very possibly so.
But you got to remember something, American people love soap operas.
(Soundbite of laughter)
I think we can handle it.
It's possible he has it out of his system or is it, you know, at least better able to hide it.
But also, I know a lot of people feel very sympathetic toward Hillary because of him.
And he might actually be garnering support for her by his actions, you know?
That last woman was Deborah Carter, who's a high school teacher.
Dennis Kucinich is her sentimental favorite.
For the Crones, the biggest concern about Clinton's electability is what the GOP might do if she is the nominee.
Liz Whitelaw sees a vicious negative campaign ahead.
I'm worried about how Karl Rove is going to be spending his retirement.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Who knows what that's going to be and it's very frightening to think about.
But I think we do have to worry.
I think we're going to have to fight very hard.
I asked if Hillary Clinton hurts the Democratic Party's chances to win.
Why pick a candidate who attract that kind of campaign?
The Crones think that campaign is coming anyway.
And Maggi Cisar pointed out that Clinton survived the Whitewater investigations and her husband's impeachment.
I think of all the Democratic candidates, that she is probably the best equipped to take on any kind of dirty tricks and the Karl Roves of the Republican Party.

The Catoctin Crones of Frederick, Maryland finding more to like about the women who may be their party's nominee in 2008.
Linda Wertheimer, NPR News.
From NPR News, this is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED.

You may recall that early in the Bush administration, the vice president refused to disclose what energy company he's had consulted on energy policy.
He fought that issue up to the court and he won.
A few days ago, we learned that Cheney sought to override the Justice Department's objections to a secret surveillance program.
The vice president's office even blocked the promotion of a senior Justice Department official who had opposed the surveillance operation.
It turns out that Cheney and other White House officials attended a secret meeting in March 2004.
They wanted Attorney General John Ashcroft from his hospital bed to approve the continuation of the possibly, illegal surveillance program.
And we learned about another of Dick Cheney's (Unintelligible) ways this past week.
The Secret Service was recently called to stop keeping logs of visitors to the president and the vice president.
You can probably figure out who wanted to hide the names of his guests - Cheney, of course.
You have to wonder who are these mysterious persons that he sees, whose identities must never be revealed.
And wait there's more.
In 2001, the White House tore up its long-standing policy of releasing presidential papers after 12 years.
The move came just in time to block the release of the Reagan papers.
That was reportedly the work of Vice President Cheney, too.
Now that we have a secretary of Homeland Security, perhaps we also need a secretary of secrecy, who would operate from an undisclosed location.
Maybe the vice president should add that to his undisclosed duties, now that his former chief of staff, Scooter Libby, is no longer available.
This is Daniel Schorr.

Trying to find a house when it does not have an address - well, on the Navajo nation, that's a pretty pretty common scenario.
A real physical address is rare.
Now though, that's beginning to change.
Reporter Carrie Jung of member station KJZZ, where I am this morning, has this story.
Paula Tso lives in a pale blue house at the end of an unpaved driveway.
She and her family have set up four homes and a traditional structure known as a hogan in this plot of windswept land in northwestern New Mexico.
Tso has lived in this area for years and knows it well.
But for out-of-towners, finding her house can be a challenge.
My nephew had a girlfriend.
And I explained the place.
You have to give, like, one and a half mile off the road of 5020.
But there's still - they don't find the road.
The girlfriend didn't find Tso's house with those directions and ended up 20 miles down the road.
While Tso can laugh at that situation, she's concerned this kind of confusion could happen when an ambulance needs to find her home.
We didn't know whether if they could find this place, or even if the police or anybody could find this place.
But that won't be the case for long.
M.C.
BALDWIN: (Foreign language spoken).
M.C.
Baldwin and his team with the Navajo Nation Rural Addressing Authority are at Tso's house today recording her information.
We're doing your sister-in-law's house, right?
It takes a lot of work to issue an address.
First, officials have to drive on tribal roads and find people's homes.
Fifty-one-hundred, left side, about two addressable structures.
But not every structure qualifies for an address, like abandoned homes or sheds.
Jesse Delmar is the tribe's public safety director.
He says the lack of home addresses is problematic for his department because the reservation spans more than 27,000 square miles, an area about the size of West Virginia.
And you have people living at every point.
And that's the biggest challenge, is trying to find some of these homes which are way out in the country.
